ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear pathology
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, significantly poorer word recognition in the left ear, unilateral tinnitus, dizziness, and elevated/absent acoustic reflexes.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Audiometric configuration shows bilateral loss with significant asymmetry (left worse than right) and complex configuration.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity and configuration given reports of progressive loss.
To assess speech understanding and check for retrocochlear signs (rollover or asymmetry).
To assess the integrity of the reflex arc and screen for retrocochlear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Audiometry reveals asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, with the left ear showing a greater degree of loss and a complex 'trough' configuration compared to the right. Word recognition is significantly poorer in the left ear (66%) compared to the right (84%), consistent with retrocochlear pathology. Tympanometry is normal bilaterally, but acoustic reflexes are generally elevated or absent. The constellation of asymmetry, poor speech scores, unilateral tinnitus, and dizziness necessitates medical referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Slight SNHL (250-2000 Hz) sloping to severe (3000-4000 Hz). Left ear: Moderately severe rising to mild (mid-frequencies) then sloping to severe. Significant asymmetry present.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT agrees with PTA. WRS shows significant asymmetry: Right 84%, Left 66%.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Thresholds generally elevated or absent, particularly at high frequencies. Contralateral decay could not be measured.

counseling_actions: Discuss the asymmetry in hearing and word recognition scores.
Explain the need for ENT referral and MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology.
Counsel on the association between unilateral symptoms (tinnitus, dizziness) and the test findings.

escalation.rationale_short: Referral for MRI to rule out retrocochlear pathology due to unexplained asymmetry, poor WRS in the left ear, and associated vestibular symptoms.
